Legal_Issue: Improper application of residency test by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's connection to other countries not fully analyzed
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied initially, then overturned on appeal
Burden_of_Proof: On Applicant to demonstrate eligibility under residency requirements
Legal_Rule: Three tests for residency: strict count of days, quality of residence, or substantial connection; judge must apply one correctly
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in legal interpretation
Procedural_Issue: Blending of two legal tests without proper analysis
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous legal application of residency test
Decision_Maker: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Justice Heneghan
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Judge failed to conduct full analysis required by law
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and nature of applicant's residence in Canada, ties to other countries
Legal_Framework: Canadian citizenship law under the Citizenship Act
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of citizenship based on residency
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of residence, travel records, personal testimony
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Residency provisions under the Citizenship Act
Governing_Rule: Residency tests under the Citizenship Act
